TaskSignal.summary: The TaskSignal interface of the Prioritized Task Scheduling API represents a signal object that allows you to communicate with a prioritized task, and abort it or change the priority (if required) via a object.

remarks.para:
An object of this type is created, and associated with, a .
The initial priority of the signal may be set by specifying it as an argument to the constructor (by default it is "user-visible").
The priority can be changed by calling on the controller.

The signal may be passed as the options.signal argument in , after which its associated controller can be used to abort the task.
If the task priority is mutable, the controller can also be used to change the task's priority.
Abortable tasks that do not need the priority to change may instead specify an as the options.signal argument.

TaskSignalAny.summary: The TaskSignal.any() static method takes an iterable of objects and returns a . The returned task signal is aborted when any of the abort signals is aborted.

remarks.para: When the task signal is aborted, its property will be set to the reason of the first signal that is aborted.

TaskSignalPriority.summary: The read-only priority property of the interface indicates the signal priority.

remarks.para:
The initial value is set in the associated by specifying it as an argument to the TaskController constructor (by default it is "user-visible").
The priority of the signal can be changed by calling on the associated controller.

For tasks with a mutable priority, this value is used to set the initial task priority and later to change it.
Tasks with an immutable priority will ignore the value.

TaskSignalPriority.value:
A string indicating the signal priority.
This will be one of: "user-blocking", "user-visible", "background".
